TipProject Snapshot



Role: AI Developer & Researcher Client: Wall Consultant Group Outcome: Automated street scoring pipeline

title: AI-Driven Walkability Assessment
text:
Overview
Assessing the “walkability” of a street usually requires expensive manual audits. In this project, I developed a scalable pipeline to automate this process using street-level imagery.

title: AI-Driven Walkability Assessment
text:
Methodology
We identified key urban design elements that influence pedestrian comfort and prepared deep learning models to process thousands of images and assign quality scores.

Data Collection: Systematically collected street-level imagery across the network.
Model Architecture: Utilized Computer Vision models to classify design elements (e.g., enclosure, greenery).
Scoring: Developed a methodology to aggregate detections into a “Streetscape Design Quality” rating.

title: AI-Driven Walkability Assessment
text:
Tech Stack

Python (PyTorch/TensorFlow)
ArcGIS for spatial visualization
Google Street View API

title: AI-Driven Walkability Assessment
text:
Impact
This tool allows planners to objectively visualize street quality and prioritize interventions without the need for exhaustive manual fieldwork.

title: The Data Bike: Trail Accessibility
text: As a Graduate Research Assistant at the University of Utah, I helped develop a low-cost “Data Bike” to assess trail conditions for users with limited mobility. The system produces actionable recommendations for maintenance, ensuring trails meet accessibility standards for all users.

title: The Data Bike: Trail Accessibility
text: As a Graduate Research Assistant at the University of Utah, I helped develop a low-cost “Data Bike” to assess trail conditions for users with limited mobility. The system produces actionable recommendations for maintenance, ensuring trails meet accessibility standards for all users.

title: The Data Bike: Trail Accessibility
text:
The System
The bike is instrumented with GPS, cameras, and accelerometers. My specific role involved:

Data Processing: Creating workflows to fuse sensor data with video feeds.
Computer Vision: Applying AI techniques to detect surface roughness, clear zones, and gradient changes.







NoteOutcomes



The system successfully identifies hazards and roughness, providing an automated method for ensuring trails remain accessible to users with disabilities.
